speaker: Socrates
claim: The oracle declared no one wiser than Socrates because he alone recognises his own ignorance.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Human wisdom is worth little or nothing compared to divine wisdom.
context: Socrates’ mission to examine those reputed wise.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The unexamined life is not worth living for a human being.
context: Refusal to abandon philosophy even under threat of death.

speaker: Socrates
claim: It is never right to disobey the god or to fear death.

speaker: Socrates
claim: No evil can happen to a good man, either in life or after death.

speaker: Socrates
claim: One must never do wrong, not even in return for wrong suffered.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Piety cannot be what is loved by the gods, since the gods disagree about what they love.
context: First form of the Euthyphro dilemma.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The pious is loved by the gods because it is pious; piety is prior to divine approval.

speaker: Laches
claim: Courage is remaining at one’s post and not fleeing.

speaker: Laches
claim: Courage is wise endurance of the soul.

speaker: Nicias
claim: Courage is knowledge of what is and is not to be feared in war and all circumstances.

speaker: Socrates
claim: If courage is knowledge of all good and evil, it coincides with virtue entire.
context: Collapse of Nicias’ definition into the unity of virtue.

speaker: Charmides
claim: Temperance is quietness / modesty.

speaker: Critias
claim: Temperance is doing our own business.

speaker: Socrates
claim: A science of science (knowledge of knowledge) would have no specific object and is impossible.

speaker: Socrates
claim: All virtues are one; they differ only in their object, not in essence.

speaker: Socrates
claim: No one does wrong willingly; wrongdoing is always due to ignorance of the good.
context: Denial of akrasia via hedonist premise.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Rhetoric is not a genuine art but a form of flattery, counterpart to cookery.

speaker: Socrates
claim: It is better to suffer injustice than to commit it.

speaker: Callicles
claim: Natural justice is the stronger ruling the weaker and having more.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Poetry and myth must be strictly censored; no depictions of gods doing evil, heroes lamenting, or the underworld as terrifying.
context: First wave of censorship in music and poetry.

speaker: Socrates
claim: We must forbid stories that represent the gods as changeable or deceitful.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Only Dorian and Phrygian modes are permitted; others produce softness or effeminacy.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Physical training must be simple and support courage, not produce mere beasts or athletes.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Guardians must hold women, children, and property in common.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Luxury and excessive wealth are the greatest sources of corruption in cities.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The three waves: (1) equality of women in guardianship, (2) abolition of private family among rulers, (3) philosopher-kings.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Women must train and rule alongside men; nature differs only in degree of strength.
context: Equality of the sexes in the guardian class.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Until philosophers rule as kings or kings become philosophers, cities will have no rest from evil.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Philosophers love truth above all and are free from petty desires.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The philosopher imitates the eternal Forms and becomes as divine as humanly possible.

speaker: Socrates
claim: We have only a dim conception of the Good itself.
context: Limit of knowledge of the Good.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The Allegory of the Cave: education is turning the soul from shadows to the real.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Education is not putting sight into blind eyes but turning the soul toward the light.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Dialectic is the capstone of the sciences and alone reaches true being.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The curriculum for philosopher-rulers: arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, harmonics, then dialectic.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The ideal city exists only in heaven as a pattern for the earthly city.
context: City in speech vs. real city.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The soul is immortal and has had many incarnations.
context: Argument from the nature of the soul.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Virtue has no master; each chooses their own daemon and fate.

speaker: Aristophanes
claim: Humans were originally double beings split by Zeus; love is the search for our lost half.

speaker: Diotima
claim: Love is a great daimon, intermediary between gods and mortals.

speaker: Diotima
claim: True eros ascends from beautiful bodies → souls → laws → sciences → the Form of Beauty itself.

speaker: Diotima
claim: The Form of Beauty is eternal, unchanging, absolute, beheld by intellect alone.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The soul is self-moving and therefore immortal.
context: First proof of immortality in Phaedrus.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The soul is a winged charioteer with two horses (reason, spirit, appetite).

speaker: Socrates
claim: The method of collection and division is the true art of dialectic.

speaker: Socrates
claim: No true art of rhetoric exists without knowledge of the soul and of truth.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Knowledge is not perception; Protagoras’ ‘man is the measure’ is self-refuting.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Knowledge is not true belief.

speaker: Socrates
claim: Knowledge is not true belief with an account; the dialogue ends in aporia.

speaker: Eleatic Stranger
claim: Being is neither only rest (Parmenides) nor only motion (Heraclitus); true reality includes both.

speaker: Eleatic Stranger
claim: The greatest kinds (being, same, other, rest, motion) interweave; every Form partakes of being, sameness, and difference.

speaker: Eleatic Stranger
claim: Not-being is difference; it has a nature of its own and is not the opposite of being.
context: Solution to the problem of falsehood.

speaker: Eleatic Stranger
claim: The true statesman rules by expert knowledge, not by laws, lot, or force.

speaker: Eleatic Stranger
claim: Laws are second-best; the expert ruler adapts to circumstances like a doctor.

speaker: Eleatic Stranger
claim: The best state weaves courageous and moderate citizens together through true opinion and divine bonds.

speaker: Young Socrates
claim: There are separate Forms for likeness, justice, beauty, and goodness.

speaker: Parmenides
claim: If Forms are thoughts, they cannot be separate; if paradigms, the third-man regress arises.
context: First objections to the theory of Forms.

speaker: Parmenides
claim: Without separate Forms, philosophy itself is impossible.

speaker: Timaeus
claim: The cosmos is a living creature with soul and reason, made by a benevolent Demiurge after an eternal paradigm.

speaker: Timaeus
claim: The world-soul is constructed from Sameness, Difference, and Being, placed in circular motion.

speaker: Timaeus
claim: Human souls are made by the Demiurge; lesser gods fashion mortal bodies.

speaker: Timaeus
claim: Time is a moving image of eternity; the heavens are ordered by mathematical necessity.
context: Creation of time and celestial order.

speaker: Timaeus
claim: The human body and soul are constructed with tripartite soul and corresponding organs.

speaker: Critias
claim: Ancient Athens was the ideal state described in the Republic; Atlantis was its arrogant opponent.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The dialectical method of collection and division is required to find the good.

speaker: Socrates
claim: There are four kinds: limit, unlimited, mixture, and cause.

speaker: Socrates
claim: The good human life is a mixture dominated by mind, measure, and truth, not pleasure.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: The best laws imitate the rule of the wise man rather than majority vote.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Humans are puppets of the gods; reason is the golden cord, passions the iron cords.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Education is the drawing of the soul toward the good through music and gymnastics.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: The only true criterion for music is whether it represents moral character correctly.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Pleasure is not the proper standard for judging art; correctness and benefit are.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: The greatest ignorance is to love what one knows to be evil and hate what is good.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: The ruler must be younger than the laws; law is the rule of reason, not men.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: The age of the Cronos myth was ruled by divine daimons; human rule is second-best.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: God, not man, is the measure of all things.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Impiety arises from believing the gods do not exist, or do not care, or can be bribed.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Marriage is for the sake of producing children for the city and continuing the race.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Women must eat together with men and be trained in military and civic duties.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Comedy must be performed only by slaves and foreigners; citizens must never mock each other.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Sexual intercourse must be limited to procreation within marriage; all else is unnatural.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Punishment is not vengeance but cure and deterrence.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: Soul is the oldest thing, prior to body, and the cause of all motion and change.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: The Nocturnal Council of elders and younger guardians is the guardian of the state’s salvation.

speaker: Plato
claim: True philosophy cannot be written down; it arises only through long communion and sudden illumination.
context: Rejection of writing on ultimate matters.

speaker: Plato
claim: Dionysius’ book on philosophy proves he understands nothing of the subject.

speaker: Athenian Stranger
claim: The highest science is theology; the guardians must master astronomy and dialectic to defend the laws.
context: Final purpose of the Nocturnal Council.
